title: 10  Population density maps
text:
Load all necessary packages by using pacman package manager


pacman::p_load(tidyverse, stringr, sf, RColorBrewer, leaflet, ggplot2, ggthemes, patchwork, plotly, ggrepel)

Load the shapefile of Bangladesh admin level 1 which represents the divisions.

bd1_shp <- st_read("data/shapefile/bd_adm1_shp/bgd_admbnda_adm1_bbs_20201113.shp")
bd2_shp <- st_read("data/shapefile/bd_adm2_shp/bgd_admbnda_adm2_bbs_20201113.shp")
bd3_shp <- st_read("data/shapefile/bd_adm3_shp/bgd_admbnda_adm3_bbs_20201113.shp")


Observe the data inside the shape file


bd1_shp


bd2_shp


bd3_shp


Check the geographic coordinate system of your shapefile


st_crs(bd1_shp)


st_crs(bd2_shp)


st_crs(bd3_shp)


Plot the map and show the name of the divisions


ggplot(bd1_shp) +
  geom_sf() + 
  geom_sf_text(aes(label = ADM1_EN), size = 2) 









ggplot(bd2_shp) +
  geom_sf() 









ggplot(bd3_shp) +
  geom_sf() 









Prepare a custom theme to make the visualization of this map better than previous default version


theme_custom_map <- function(base_size = 11,
                             base_family = "",
                             base_line_size = base_size / 22,
                             base_rect_size = base_size / 22) {
    theme_bw(base_size = base_size, 
             base_family = base_family,
             base_line_size = base_line_size) %+replace%
        theme(
            axis.title = element_blank(), 
            axis.text = element_blank(),
            axis.ticks = element_blank(),
            complete = TRUE
        )
}


ggplot(bd1_shp) +
  geom_sf() +
  geom_sf_text(aes(label = ADM1_EN), size = 2) +
  theme_custom_map()









ggplot(bd2_shp) +
  geom_sf() +
   theme_custom_map()









ggplot(bd3_shp) +
  geom_sf() +
   theme_custom_map()









Import population data of all divisions of Bangladesh


bd1_pop <- read.csv("data/csv/bd_pop_adm1_2022.csv")
bd2_pop <- read.csv("data/csv/bd_pop_adm2_2022.csv")
bd3_pop <- read.csv("data/csv/bd_pop_adm3_2022.csv")


Merge the shapefile and csv data-set


bd1_shp_pop <- merge(bd1_shp, bd1_pop, by=c("ADM1_PCODE"))
bd1_shp_pop <- st_make_valid(bd1_shp_pop)
glimpse(bd1_shp_pop)


bd2_shp_pop <- merge(bd2_shp, bd2_pop, by=c("ADM2_PCODE"))
bd2_shp_pop <- st_make_valid(bd2_shp_pop)
glimpse(bd2_shp_pop)


bd3_shp_pop <- merge(bd3_shp, bd3_pop, by=c("ADM3_PCODE"))
bd3_shp_pop <- st_make_valid(bd3_shp_pop)
glimpse(bd3_shp_pop)


Draw the map ADM1


ggplot(bd1_shp_pop) +
    geom_sf(aes(fill=F_TL), color = "white", lwd = 0.07) +
    geom_sf_text(aes(label = ADM1_EN), size = 2) +
    scale_fill_viridis_c(option = "magma", name = "Population") +
    theme_map() + 
    theme(legend.direction="horizontal") +
     labs(title = "Divisions of Bangladesh", 
         subtitle = "Population density of Bangladesh", 
         caption = "Source of data: BBS")









Draw the map ADM2


ggplot(bd2_shp_pop) +
    geom_sf(aes(fill=F_TL), color = "white", lwd = 0.07) +
    #geom_sf_text(aes(label = ADM2_EN), size = 2) +
    scale_fill_viridis_c(option = "magma", name = "Population") +
    theme_map() + 
    theme(legend.direction="horizontal") +
     labs(title = "Districts of Bangladesh", 
         subtitle = "Population density of Bangladesh", 
         caption = "Source of data: BBS")









Draw the map ADM3


ggplot(bd3_shp_pop) +
    geom_sf(aes(fill=F_TL), color = "white", lwd = 0.07) +
    #geom_sf_text(aes(label = ADM2_EN), size = 2) +
    scale_fill_viridis_c(option = "magma", name = "Population") +
    theme_map() + 
    theme(legend.direction="horizontal") +
     labs(title = "Upazila/Thana of Bangladesh", 
         subtitle = "Population density of Bangladesh", 
         caption = "Source of data: BBS")

title: 11  Creating a final report
text:
11.1 A quarto book
Quarto Books are combinations of multiple documents (chapters) into a single manuscript. Books can be created in a variety of formats:

title: 11  Creating a final report
text:
11.2 Workflow
We will check the steps to create and edit a simple book with chapters contained in the files index.qmd, intro.qmd, summary.qmd.
Config File
A Quarto project file (_quarto.yml) is contained within the book project directory. This file contains the initial configuration for your book. For example:
---
project:
  type: book
book:
  title: "GIS with R"
  author: "Moinul Islam"
  date: "4/18/2024"
  chapters:
    - index.qmd
    - intro.qmd
    - summary.qmd
    - references.qmd
bibliography: references.bib
format:
  html:
    theme: cosmo
  pdf:
    documentclass: scrreprt
  epub:
    cover-image: cover.png
---

title: 11  Creating a final report
text:
11.3 Book Structure
The structure of a Quarto book can be as simple as a list of chapters, or can alternatively incorporate multiple parts and/or appendices. Quarto book chapters and sections are automatically numbered (for cross-referencing), however you can also specify that some parts of the book should remain unnumbered.
The simple book configuration generated by quarto create project book illustrates the basics:
---
book:
  title: "GIS with R"
  author: "Moinul Islam"
  date: "5/9/2021"
  chapters:
    - index.qmd
    - intro.qmd
    - summary.qmd
    - references.qmd
---
The index.qmd file is required (because Quarto books also produce a website in HTML format). The references.qmd file will include the generated bibliography.
Titles
Since rendering options are provided in _quarto.yml, you’ll typically see a simple level-one header at the top of chapters. For example:
# Introduction
Note that the following is also still perfectly valid:
---
title: "Introduction"
---
In the absence of a level-one header or a title set in the YAML front matter, the first header in the page will be used as the title.
Chapter Numbers
All chapters are numbered by default. If you want a chapter to be unnumbered simply add the .unnumbered class to its main header. For example:
# Introduction {.unnumbered}
Section Numbers
You can set the numbering depth via the number-depth option. For example, to only number sections immediately below the chapter level, use this:
number-depth: 1
Creating an Index
To add an index to the PDF output for a book, add these include-in-header and include-after-body entries to your pdf format configuration in _quarto.yml: quart
---
format:
  html:
    theme: cosmo
  pdf:
    documentclass: scrreprt
    include-in-header: 
      text: |
        \usepackage{makeidx}
        \makeindex
    include-after-body: 
      text: |
        \printindex
---
Parts & Appendices
You can divide your book into parts using part within the book chapters. For example:
---
chapters:
  - index.qmd
  - preface.qmd
  - part: dice.qmd
    chapters: 
      - basics.qmd
      - packages.qmd
  - part: cards.qmd
    chapters:
      - objects.qmd
      - notation.qmd
      - modifying.qmd
      - environments.qmd
---
You can include appendices by adding an appendices key to your book config. For example:
---
book:
  title: "GIS with R"
  author: "Moinul Islam"
  date: "5/9/2024"
  chapters:
    - index.qmd
    - intro.qmd
    - summary.qmd
    - references.qmd
  appendices:
    - tools.qmd
    - resources.qmd
---
Navigation bar
Options that define the top navigation bar for a book For example:
---
book:
  navbar:
    search: true
---
Navigation items
Nav items appear in the left or right key of navbar definitions, or contents key of sidebar definitions. For example:
---
book:
  navbar:
    right:
      - icon: github
        href: https://github.com/
        aria-label: GitHub
---
Sidebar
Options that define the side navigation area for a book. For example:
---
book:
  sidebar:
    search: true
---
Sidebar Tools
Action buttons that appear on the sidebar. For example:
---
book:
  sidebar:
    tools:
      - icon: github
        href: https://github.com/
---

title: References
text:
Lovelace, R., Nowosad, J., and Muenchow, J. (2019). Geocomputation with R. CRC Press.
Comber, L., and Brunsdon, C. (2020). Geographical Data Science and Spatial Data Analysis: An Introduction in R. Sage.
Kopczewska, K. (2020). Applied Spatial Statistics and Econometrics: Data Analysis in R. Routledge.

title: 1  R packages for GIS
text:
1.2 R packages for GIS:

1.2.1 Basic data manipulation

sf [for vector data]


CRAN install.packages("sf")
GitHub remotes::install_github("r-spatial/sf")

sf package installation in Windows OS is straight frward. And the above codes should be sufficient to install sf. However, in MacOS and Linux (Ubuntu/Fedora), some additional steps are necessary.

For MacOS

– First we need to install gdal and the easiest way to install gdal is using Homebrew.
brew install pkg-config
brew install gdal
– Next we need to install sf by using following command.
install.packages("sf", type = "source", configure.args = "--with-proj-lib=$(brew --prefix)/lib/")

raster [for raster data]


CRAN install.packages("raster")
GitHub remotes::install_github("rspatial/raster")


shapefiles


CRAN install.packages("shapefiles")


ncdf4


CRAN install.packages(“ncdf4”)
GitHub devtools::install_github("mdsumner/ncdf4")


sp


CRAN install.packages("sp", dependencies=TRUE)
GitHub devtools::install_github("edzer/sp")



1.2.2 Cartography and data visualization

tidyverse [Includes the packages ggplot2, dplyr, tidyr, readr, purrr, tibble, stringr, forcats]


CRAN install.packages("tidyverse")
GitHub pak::pak("tidyverse/tidyverse")

GGally [Extends ggplot2 by adding several functions to reduce the complexity of combining geometric objects with transformed data]


CRAN install.packages("GGally")
GitHub devtools::install_github("ggobi/ggally")


grid [A set of graphical functions which support a great deal of flexibility in the layout of graphics]


CRAN install.packages("grid")

gridExtra [Provides a number of user-level functions to work with “grid” graphics, notably to arrange multiple grid-based plots on a page, and draw tables]


CRAN install.packages("gridExtra")

cartogram [Construct continuous and non-contiguous area cartograms]

Cran
GitHub

title: 6  Making map of Tokyo
text:
6.1 Population Map of Tokyo
df_tokyo_sf <- jpn_pref(13, district = TRUE) %>% 
  dplyr::filter(str_detect(city, "区"))
df_tokyo_sf %>%
  ggplot() +
  geom_sf() +
  theme_minimal()
head(df_tokyo_sf, 23)

Simple feature collection with 23 features and 4 fields
Geometry type: MULTIPOLYGON
Dimension:     XY
Bounding box:  xmin: 139.5636 ymin: 35.52086 xmax: 139.919 ymax: 35.81758
Geodetic CRS:  WGS 84
# A tibble: 23 × 5
   pref_code prefecture city_code city                                  geometry
   <chr>     <chr>      <chr>     <chr>                       <MULTIPOLYGON [°]>
 1 13        東京都     13101     千代田区 (((139.7299 35.68555, 139.7333 35.67…
 2 13        東京都     13102     中央区   (((139.7589 35.65892, 139.7646 35.65…
 3 13        東京都     13103     港区     (((139.7714 35.62304, 139.7825 35.62…
 4 13        東京都     13104     新宿区   (((139.6735 35.71852, 139.679 35.718…
 5 13        東京都     13105     文京区   (((139.7174 35.71455, 139.7232 35.71…
 6 13        東京都     13106     台東区   (((139.7632 35.72184, 139.7685 35.71…
 7 13        東京都     13107     墨田区   (((139.8095 35.68689, 139.812 35.688…
 8 13        東京都     13108     江東区   (((139.7715 35.61667, 139.7712 35.61…
 9 13        東京都     13109     品川区   (((139.6954 35.60832, 139.6957 35.61…
10 13        東京都     13110     目黒区   (((139.6664 35.61861, 139.6631 35.61…
# ℹ 13 more rows
df_tokyo_pop <- read_csv("data/csv/tokyo_pop.csv")
datatable(df_tokyo_pop)
merge_tokyo <- df_tokyo_sf %>% 
  left_join(df_tokyo_pop, by = "city") %>% 
  st_as_sf()
merge_tokyo %>% 
  head() %>% 
  rmarkdown::paged_table()
map_pop_tokyo <- merge_tokyo %>% 
  ggplot() +
  geom_sf(aes(fill = population)) +
  scale_fill_distiller(name = "Population",
                       palette = "Greens", direction = 1) +
  theme_map(base_family = "HiraginoSans-W3") +
  theme(legend.position = c(.1, -.1),
        legend.direction = "horizontal",
        legend.title = element_text(size = 15), 
        legend.text = element_text(size = 15),
        legend.key.size = unit(1, "cm"),
        legend.key.width = unit(3,"cm")) +
  coord_sf(datum = NA) 

map_pop_tokyo




Population of Tokyo, Japan
map_pop_tokyo_text <- merge_tokyo %>% 
  mutate(
    text_x = map_dbl(geometry, ~st_centroid(.x)[[1]]),
    text_y = map_dbl(geometry, ~st_centroid(.x)[[2]])
  ) %>% 
  ggplot() +
  geom_sf(aes(fill = population)) +
  geom_label(aes(x = text_x, y = text_y, label = city), 
             size = 1.7, family = "HiraginoSans-W3") +
  scale_fill_distiller(name = "Population",
                       palette = "Greens", direction = 1) +
  theme_map(base_family = "HiraginoSans-W3") +
  theme(legend.position = c(.8, .05),
        legend.title = element_text(size = 10), 
        legend.text = element_text(size = 5),
        legend.key.size = unit(0.5, "cm"),
        legend.key.width = unit(1,"cm")) +
  coord_sf(datum = NA) 

map_pop_tokyo_text




Population of Tokyo, Japan
ggsave("fig/map_pop_tokyo_text.png", map_pop_tokyo_text, width = 13, height = 13)

title: 6  Making map of Tokyo
text:
The prefecture code for Tokyo is 13. Now we can plot the map of the 23 wards of Tokyo



Display the extracted map of Tokyo’s 23 wards



Check your data here



Import the .CSV data to make an interactive population map of Tokyo



Merge the spatial data with your population data



Check the merged data



Plot your data with ggplot2



Plot your population data with the name of the cities in Tokyo



To export the above figure, use the following code:
